subject: Last Year (Travel and Conventions)
event:
I did a lot of travelling last year.  Probably too much.  You don't have to chide me about that.  I know, believe me, I know.  I am trying to cut down on travel this year and in subsequent years, at least until Ice & Fire is done.

But it's a struggle.  I love travel -- not the flying, but being there, seeing other parts of the world, meeting my readers.  As a kid, I never went anywhere at all except in my imagination, so now, when I have the means, travel is hard to resist.  It's a big wonderful world.

Also, I am not getting any younger (some of you love to remind me of that).  Travel is fun, but it can also be taxing.  I am all too aware that if I don't take some of these trips now, age and health may preclude my ever taking them.  Who knows what awaits me (or you, or you, or you) five years or ten years down the road?

Some of the travel I did in 2015 was for business, or to attend conventions that I had committed to two, three, four, even five years ago.  Other travel was more spontaneous.  A nephew's wedding.  An invitation to the SuperBowl.  The last Grateful Dead concerts.  People keep making me offers I cannot refuse... and not just Don Corleone...

Anyway... I travelled, and mostly I am glad I did... I wrote a couple of pages about my various trips and conventions in the Lost Post, and included plenty of pictures.  I am not going to bother redoing any of that.  I fear that only a few of you are interested in my travels.  Many would rather I never ever got up from my computer.

So no rehash of the rehash.

I will say that I had a great time in San Francisco at the GAME OF THRONES premiere parties, that ConQuest in KC was something special, and that my summer trip to Germany, Sweden, and Finland was one I will long remember and cherish.  Stockholm is a gorgeous city that I want to see again, and I had a fantastic time in Hamburg hanging with the beautiful and talented Sibel Kekilli, her guy Andreas, and my old agent and friend Werner Fuchs.  The con was fun too; Finnish fans are tops, and I look forward to Helsinki in two years.

As for worldcon... I have been going to worldcons since 1971, it is always one of the highlights of my year, and Sasquan was no different, despite the whole state seemingly being on fire, and the tensions created by the Recent Unpleasantness With Young Dogs.  The Hugo Awards were... ah... a mixed bag, but I was pleased to reclaim my Hugo Losers Party.  We kicked ass there, yes we did, and I'm only sorry Gardner Dozois was not with us in Spokane to be part of it.  

Travel and cons.  'Nuff said.

comments.article:
Europe pics please.üôèüèº

Just a few perhaps? Those you'd like landlocked Americans to see . . .
comments.subject: Europe pics please

comments.article: Did you read the blog where Martin indicates that people keep distracting him from writing by asking him to go places and do things. I'm sure many people would love to see his pictures, but if he doesn't already have it on his schedule, why are you putting one more thing on his "To Do" list?
comments.subject: Re: Europe pics please

comments.article:
"...that ConQuest in KC was something special"

I seem to recall you were a champion of KC getting WorldCon this year, as well. I'm a native, and I don't have the money to go to a WorldCon anywhere else, so my thanks for that.

May I chalk it up to an appreciation of good barbecue?

Love KC barbeque. Especially burnt ends.

But I have a long love affair with KC fandom that goes way deeper.

And Big Mac in 1976 was the Best Worldcon Of All Time, IMNSHO. (Even though I lost two Hugos there).
I loved seeing you in person in Hamburg, it was a fun evening. Hope you will be able to return to Germany (or at least Europe) in future time :)
If you were the master of both time and space, where would you go?
I do envy Doctor Who his TARDIS.

The tone of this post makes me sad ("some of you love to remind me of [your mortality]" and "Many would rather I never ever got up from my computer"). I feel shitty about how bad the fandom's relationship with you has gotten.

I can sympathize with the mentality of some of the more rabid fans, I know how they got there and have the same impulses. But I also hope you take all your chances to travel and enjoy life. You've earned your position and deserve some leisure.

It's not everyone. Most of my fans are great.

But it's enough to be annoying.
These blog posts are great. Helping me get work done tonight, while I periodically read the Cliffnotes.
comments.subject: Travel

comments.article:
I'm copying exactly what i posted on a reddit thread on these updates. This post really hit me hard.

"That last post made me kind of sad. My husband has never been able to travel. The furthest he has been from where he was born is 3 hours. If he was suddenly handed the ability to do whatever he wanted, he would too. GRRM is given all these amazing opportunities, do you really think any of us would be different? He wants to travel, he wants to go to these things but he feels chained to his computer, so of course writing now feels like a chore. Who is excited to do chores? As much as I want the series to end and for him to finish his books, I would never want someone to sacrifice their happiness for the pleasure I get from a story. Sure this will make a lot of you mad, but everyone deserves happiness. Most of us would do the same thing in his position."
comments.subject: Reddit comment

comments.article: Exactly!
comments.subject: RE: Reddit comment

comments.article: hey george happy new year i just want to thank you for everything you have done and accomplished you have been and sill a great influence on me I'm currently writing a dark epic fantasy book planned to be composed of five and you still a great influence you and tolkien and neil on me and the fantasy genre and literature in general so i thank you again and hop for you a long happy and successful live to accomplish your great ambitions and remember no matter what happens you will and still our george eternal and immortal in that single but great spot both on my mind and heart living there forever and that's all from me love frome Kuwait ( yes george you are global more than ever )
comments.subject: thanks George

comments.article: Forgive your fans. We're can be such a**holes but we do love you and wish you happiness. Thank you for everything. Even if you do not write the rest of the series, it still was a lot of fun and I do not regret a minute that I have invested in your work, Mr. George. You can ignore this comment and not approve it in your blog, but I really just want you to know.
comments.subject: sorry

comments.article: The vast majority of my fans are great.
comments.subject: Re: sorry

comments.article: It's important, I think, for a writer to travel as much as possible. Staying in one place is god awful for the imagination. It's not healthy because you begin to write too much of yourself and the results can end up, while no less beautiful, quite depressing. This is something I know from experience. Think: the Bront√´ siblings.
comments.subject: Travels

comments.article: I, personally love hearing about your travels. Sometimes I'm jealous of those fans who get your attention, sometimes I'm jealous of you and how much traveling you get to do! :)  Mostly, I love hearing about your P.O.V. and what you're doing.  I think traveling contributes to your writing, it's important for you and your creativity.
But how were the Dead shows? Did Trey do it for you on guitar? Where you like, "Seriously, you're not going to play fucking "Dire Wolf"?
comments.subject: Dead shows

comments.article: Actually, "Ripple" is my favorite, and they did play that.
comments.subject: Re: Dead shows

comments.article:
George, I was also brought up in circumstances that didn't allow me to travel. As an adult I've been lucky enough to change that, and that beautiful sense of wonder is hard to describe, particularly when one is deprived of it for so long.

Travel and your amazing work are the two things that keep me going. As much as I adore the world you created, you are a human being who deserves a full life with as much happiness as you can find. All the best, and thank you for everything.
comments.subject: Travel

comments.article: If you(anyone) love something just do that, don't think about what others(we-fans)say.Enjoy the life.I too love travelling the world. I saw  your travel pics in posts.Those are great.Be healthy and be happy :-).
comments.subject: Great...

comments.article:
Live Journal must have eaten my post, too.

I was struck by the tone of your post, too, and also wanted to say that you should go wherever you want to go, and experience life while you still can. Carpe diem. I, too, am a book lover, but also just a human being. I can wait for your next books, books that I hope that you will write without feeling chained to your computer. You may have a devoted fan base, but we are also a fan base in that interesting interregnum of the "not knowing" what happens. It is an interesting, creative place to be, and one we won't have forever. There is something to be said for anticipation; it makes the waiting sweeter.
Happy New Year, and safe travels to Exciting New Places. And thank you for all you do, whether writing great stories, or making your community a better place.
comments.subject: Life is short...

comments.article:
The good part of all the nagging, or chiding, is that so many people love your work, and while we fans are anxious to find out what happens next the fact that we have plunked down money to buy material over which you worked hard to produce in the past does not mean that we "own" you in any way. Your life is your own. No fan has any legitimate say in how you spend your time. We can wish, and lobby, but what really matters is what makes you happy.

My mom had a few holiday dishes that she made that were really delicious, but very difficult to make. She didn't make them every holiday. She enjoyed showing how much she loved us with her cooking, but it was up to her to do with her time what she wanted. Would they have tasted the same if she did them out of a sense of obligation? I think not.

I like reading all you're posts , it's great to know at times you are just as sad/grumpy/happy/joyous as the rest of us mundane lot :D .

Best wishes to you and yours Mr Martin for a great year ahead
comments.subject: Thank you

comments.article:
I've never commented on the Not A Blog before, but I felt compelled to after reading this post.

"I fear that only a few of you are interested in my travels. Many would rather I never ever got up from my computer."

It makes me sad that people make you feel this way, it really does. While I am most certainly (impatiently) awaiting a release date for THE WINDS OF WINTER like anyone else who loves your story‚Äìand is antsy to see where it goes‚Äìit's rude and a little dehumanizing that people badger you so thoroughly about it. I see it in the replies to practically every post on Twitter, and the comments are not always the most polite about it, so I imagine it's 10x as obnoxious on your end.

One negative comment can feel more impactful than ten kind ones, unfortunately (and also unfortunately, they're far easier to come by online)....so even if you get tens of comments with this same sentiment as me, I do think you should hear it more: take your time. Enjoy life. Travel, feast, and frolic all you like, and don't let anyone make you feel guilty for it!! These are things you're entitled to and anyone who truly thinks you should remain on house arrest until you finish your novels must not have ever created anything for themselves. It is death to the creative mind, to not live life to its fullest potential and not take in and enjoy the world around you. I for one (and for many, surely) do appreciate seeing the author of my favorite series getting out there and living his life to its fullest, and sharing these experiences with his fans. You even gave us sample chapters from TWOW this year, for which I'm very grateful; I can't articulate how much it meant to me to get the Alayne one in particular, but believe me, it was everything.

In 2016, I would love to see MORE GRRM selfies taken from all over the world, not less! Because you're a person, not a tool we are entitled to receive constant entertainment from. I will be on the edge of my seat as I await the opportunity to hold a new book in my hands....but I also trust your process, and understand that there's no one who cares more about this story than you do. :) I'd rather your progress on this series be a joy, not an obligation.

So, you do you, George! <3

Thank you for the kind words and support.

Don't really take selfies, but I do take pictures. Not enough of them, probably. And not very good. But other people sometimes take pictures and send them to me, and those are often better.

You were in Finland on the Aland islands (may have butchered that spelling) at the same time as my mom last summer, George! She was super sad she missed a chance meeting thousands of miles from the homeland!
comments.subject: Finland

comments.article: Aland is such a small place too.
comments.subject: Re: Finland

comments.article:
Hello! Your entry got to top-25 of the most popular entries in LiveJournal!
Learn more about LiveJournal Ratings in FAQ.

I think you had the best response to the types of people making demands [insert image of you flipping them all off] - I believe me including this image led to my comment being marked as spam; sorry about the two comments if the spam message was an error.

I myself am very grateful to have the opportunity to hear you read from The World of Ice and Fire and The Winds of Winter, ask you questions, and enjoy the large ASOIAF/BWB presence at cons you are guesting at (as if the first two weren't enough!). It's rather addictive, and just the best feeling to be surrounded by so many people with similar interests.


I am particularly excited to hear you read at Mysticon and Balticon - and particularly hopeful to hear something from Fire and Blood.

I am sorry to hear about the Lost Post; I would have loved to see those photos!
Fire and Blood?  Not Winds?  Interesting.

I will always love and enjoy pictures :)

Edited to add - I love LJ for a variety of reasons, but losing long, thoughtful, or otherwise involved posts is something I wish upon no person. It is a painful defeat, and I empathize with your loss.
Hope to see you in KC for Worldcon!

I'm personally thrilled you are still traveling and doing a few cons. Nothing makes me happier than being in a new place checking out their local haunts. I am looking forward to seeing you in the spring at Balticon.
comments.subject: Cons

comments.article:
Hey. I, and a lot of us as well, we support you. You don't need to write for us. We enjoy reading it, even with all the tears and the heartache you inflict on us through the characters with whom we identify and empathize. It's your story to tell though, in your way and in your time. Write for yourself.

We wait with the patience of the dead. What is dead may never die.
comments.subject: Writing
